The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum theory. This is a significant advance over previous attempts to provide a categorical foundation of quantum theory, which were based on assumptions about the structure of Hilbert space. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to the scientific community and to the public because of their extreme reduction in body plan and the potential for developing treatments for human diseases such as cancer and tuberculosis. Here, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two myxozoan species, which represent the most complete analyses of myxozoan genomes to date. Our results provide insights into the extreme reduction in body plan and gene content that is characteristic of the Myxozoa and suggest that the myxozoan transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import of cargo proteins. We show that Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex is required for its ability to block nuclear import of cargo proteins and impair the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this large population will be challenging because of the expected increase in global mean temperature. We quantify how the variability of maize production will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This increase in instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty, underscores the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. Our results also highlight the importance of considering the impact of climate change on the variability of yields in the context of food demand. (Abridged)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth and composition. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of size-matched grazers—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. These findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity. (Abridged)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, businesses have widely differing beliefs about the length of the crisis. Finally, many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. These findings suggest that the CARES Act may not be sufficient to support the survival of many small businesses.

Plastic debris is a major environmental concern, but the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total load is far less than expected. This is due to the fast fragmentation of the plastic debris into smaller particles, which are transported to the ocean interior and sink. This sink is size selective, and the removal of the millimeter-sized fragments is of the same order of magnitude as the accumulation of the plastic debris on the ocean surface. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris, and it is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This work also provides a baseline for future studies.

The origin of the Solar System is a major topic of current research. The study of presolar grains, which are formed in the interior of stars, provides information about the early stages of the Solar System. We determined the ages of 40 presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the formation of the Solar System. The majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. This indicates that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides of the grains was acquired in the interstellar medium. The study of presolar grains provides information about the formation of the Solar System and the early stages of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. In this study, we show that the evolution of sociality is associated with an increase in the energy available to the mother. We find that the evolution of sociality is associated with an increase in the energy available to the mother. This increase is associated with a larger litter size and a larger size of the offspring. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies. This would be of great importance for MSA patients, who currently have no treatment. (Show more)

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell layer that is able to control its function by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. Here, the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This is important for understanding the function of the endothelium in health and disease. This work also provides a foundation for future studies of the role of the endothelium in cardiovascular disease.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with the risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the establishment of social hierarchy, and show that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is critical for the development of a subordinate status. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns are limited by the designer’s experience. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple material phases into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to other fields, such as architecture, biology, and engineering. This work is expected to inspire the design of mechanical structures with desired responses.

The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it plays a role in the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and to the chronologic manipulation of hemoglobin expression in the human body. (Show more)

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we identified a mechanism of SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance, which involves the generation of monounsaturated fatty acids by stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). Finally, we demonstrated that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of ferroptosis resistance in cancer and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) is the most common treatment for hypertension. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of developing heart failure. Our study shows that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM/ORAI proteins. Our findings may help to improve the safety of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the policy was not effective in halting the decline of older forest-associated bird species, and that the early seral ecosystem, which is critical for many species, is also declining. These findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is often unsuccessful. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We use a computational approach to predict the activity of acylide antibiotics against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. We then synthesize the most promising compounds and test them in vitro and in vivo. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to identify new antibiotics for other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. It can also be used to identify new antibiotics for other antibiotic-sensitive pathogens. (Show more)

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous in many countries. This study shows that the use of such devices can have a negative impact on sleep, with implications for health and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a short-term cooling event that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in the Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the function of CTLA-4 is not limited to the early development of autoimmunity, but also in the maintenance of immune tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. We found that APOE isoform is highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is a major process of synapse elimination in the brain. APOE2 enhances the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with increased AD risk in part because of decreased rate of astrocytic phagocytosis. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 animals have increased accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain. These studies also reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic synapse elimination. They suggest that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of increased synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 animals have increased accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is metastable at core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our findings provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its relation to the Earth's interior. They also provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its relation to the Earth's interior. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, it is still not clear how to design stable DL algorithms. In this paper, we show that the stability of DL algorithms is closely related to the stability of the underlying mathematical models. We prove that, for a large class of mathematical models, there exists a stable DL algorithm that can compute the solution with a given accuracy. This is a fundamental result that provides a classification theory for the stability of DL algorithms. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network algorithm that is stable and provably converges in O(|log (ϵ)|/ϵ2) iterations. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the stability of DL algorithms. They also provide a new perspective on the design of stable DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the failure of science communication. The pandemic is a perfect example of exponential growth, a phenomenon that is difficult for people to grasp. In the 1970s, a classic experiment was conducted to study this phenomenon. It is now widely cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon it set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The latter is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, and that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the nervous system. This suggests that it is also neuropathogenic. Our findings have implications for the study of leprosy evolution and pathogenesis. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the integrability of the model allows for a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We compute the entanglement entropy and the entanglement spectrum, and we check them against numerical simulations. Our results provide a framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is the one developed by our group. It is based on a temperature-sensitive virus that is attenuated by codon deoptimization and has a furin cleavage site deletion. The vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, its function in normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. These findings may help to inform the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of actin dynamics. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We find that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments that are connected to each other, but not filaments that are not connected. We propose that this is due to the mechanical torque that ADF/cofilin induces on the filaments. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We believe that this work will help to elucidate the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action. It will also help to understand the role of ADF/cofilin in cells. This will be important for understanding ADF/cofilin’s role in various cellular processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food industry. It is also the preferred carbohydrate in many beverages. The present study provides evidence that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake. They also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. This may have important implications for the development of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a Bantu and an Austronesian component. The genetic history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased admixture. The genetic structure of the island is also influenced by geography, suggesting that the island was settled by different groups of people at different times. These findings are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also have implications for the interpretation of the genetic diversity of other islands in the Indian Ocean. (Less)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and the extent to which emotional contagion occurs in the real world is unclear. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, and that this influence is not limited to in-person interaction. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but their impact on protein synthesis has been less well studied. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor EF-Tu and the initiation of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a codon. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a modest impact on the rate of protein synthesis. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis and may have implications for understanding the role of Ψ in human disease. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. It also has implications for the design of work environments, which are often designed to maximize productivity and efficiency, at the expense of the sense that the things one does are worthwhile. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of all mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to the environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. Our findings reveal a previously unknown role for type IV pili in sensing the mechanical activity of the surface on which they are growing, and suggest that this sensing mechanism may be used by other bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their environment. This may be important for the regulation of surface-induced virulence and biofilm formation. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic organisms. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem and is a major step forward in the understanding of the environmental impact of pesticides.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillover back to humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 has spread between deer and humans in Iowa. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more proactive approach to prevent the spillover of SARS-CoV-2 to animals. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the challenges of incorporating climate change into the decision-making process, and the need to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the most prevalent form of dementia in the United States. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of the amyloid-β peptide (Aβ) and the tau protein in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is believed to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is a major factor in the production of an inflammatory response in neurons. This response is not seen in other brain cell types, and may be a significant factor in the development of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. It is a main source of protein for more than a billion people. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is, however, still unknown. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is to be found in the Southern Levant, where the exploitation of chickens was widespread and practiced on a large scale. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the chicken as a species and its integration into the economy. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. The best that can be done is to study the process at high resolution, as is done here. The results are important for understanding the folding process and for the design of better proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of these molecules and the extent to which they influence the fate of specific transcripts remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decape Np4-capped RNAs, also plays a major role in the deprotection of 5′ ends of transcripts that are capped with Np4. Our results suggest that the concentration of Np4 and the activity of RppH are critical factors in the control of the fate of capped transcripts in bacteria. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of Np4 in bacterial stress response and gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main player in the resolution of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of severe complications such as persistent immunosuppression. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the historical impact of humans on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. These results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit with a continuous time evolution. This is in contrast to all known models of SOC, which are discrete. We discuss the implications of our results for the theory of SOC and for the theory of continuous time evolution in general.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized under mechanical strain without phonon instability. This opens up the possibility of tailoring the electronic properties of diamond by strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by strain, which is important for understanding the phase transition to graphite. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with tailored properties. This work can help to advance the development of diamond-based technologies. This article is protected by copyright. The discovery of the first antifungal peptide, cecropin, in insects in the 1970s led to the development of a new class of antimicrobial peptides. Since then, a large number of antimicrobial peptides have been discovered in animals, plants, and microbes. However, the mode of action of most of these peptides is not known. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides from legumes. These peptides are highly diverse in sequence and exhibit potent antifungal activity against plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of these peptides is unique and is likely to be different from that of other known antifungal peptides. This work provides a new perspective on the discovery of antifungal peptides and their potential as a new class of fungicides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is distinct from that of the female reproductive tract, and we demonstrate that the male–female interface is dynamic, with sperm undergoing substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to prevent bleeding. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the observed pathophysiology. This is a simple way to understand the effects of mutations in VWF, and may be useful for other proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the study of viruses in the human microbiome, and is a resource for the study of viruses in the human body.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. We expect this technique to be widely used in the future.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is inferred to have decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of the ion flow and the regulation of the channel function. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are also important for the control of the ion flow and the regulation of the channel function. In this study, we found that the activation and inactivation of the BK channel are state-dependent and that the BK channel’s closing is closed state-dependent. These findings provide a new perspective for the study of ion channel activation and inactivation. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that has plagued humans for thousands of years. Despite the development of effective drugs, the disease remains a major public health problem. The malaria parasite, Plasmodium, is able to invade the human red blood cell (RBC) and establish a blood stage infection. The invasion process is a complex event that involves a number of parasite proteins. Here, we show that one of these proteins, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), alters the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that invasion is a complex process, in which the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, and may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does so, however, remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. We also show that the brain responds to the addition of each word or phrase with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system. (Show more)

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated in a similar fashion at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This is a very subtle feature that may be used to regulate the two forms of Axin in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. In this study, we provide a detailed characterization of the LH circuit that promotes overeating. We show that stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Finally, we show that stimulation of LH neurons promotes eating in a manner that is blocked by lesions of a critical downstream circuit element, the peri-locus coeruleus. These findings provide a framework for understanding the circuit mechanisms that promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may also have implications for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is often a limiting factor. In agriculture, the vast majority of fixed nitrogen is delivered by free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil. However, the efficiency of this process is limited by the availability of the nitrogenase enzyme complex, which is unable to fix nitrogen in the presence of oxygen. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the activity of the nitrogenase enzyme complex in the soil, by engineering a plant to produce a signaling molecule that controls the activity of the nitrogenase enzyme complex in the soil. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on agriculture, as well as on the development of synthetic biology. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to monitor and deter deforestation, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced forest loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C of warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused billions of dollars in economic losses. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. In this study, we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-established as a target for neutralizing antibodies. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the human ACE2 receptor and heterotypic binding to the RBD of the variant of concern 501Y.V1/V2. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the variant may be a useful addition to the arsenal of vaccines against COVID-19. (Show more)

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in the development and function of many tissues. In the past few years, we have identified secreted ALKAL proteins as ligands for human ALK. In this study, we show that these ALKALs are able to activate the ALK family of RTKs in vivo. This finding has important implications for the role of ALK in development and disease.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a complex process that has been poorly understood. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period of development for the pathogen. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which is a valuable contribution to our understanding of the origins of this devastating pathogen. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the top 1 m of the soil. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Mollisol can be optimized to increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC into the mineral soil. We found that the inclusion of legumes and manure into annual cropping systems, as well as rotational grazing of pastures, can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC into the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon in agricultural landscapes. This study provides a framework for the management of agricultural systems to increase soil carbon storage and mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We also provide a platform for the public to access and contribute to the ongoing refinement of the risk assessment. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. We anticipate that the platform will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is thought to be an important cue for pollinators, but the chemical basis for this cue is unknown. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent adaptation in two other species of plants visited by nectar-feeding vertebrates. These findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a common trait that is favored by natural selection and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of the chemical reward that plants offer to pollinators. (Show more)

We present a case study of a female-biased migration event that occurred in Europe during the Early Medieval period. We also show that the genetic landscape of Europe was shaped by a combination of migration and selection processes. Our results indicate that the genetic landscape of Europe was shaped by a combination of migration and selection processes.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its potential for future cross-species transmission. (Show more)

We demonstrate the feasibility of using a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the assembly of a complex, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ)–proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is stable and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and provide a foundation for future studies on the role of pol δ in human diseases. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, and neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is important for understanding the physical transformations of cities and for developing more effective policies for urban revitalization.

The study shows that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 6, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of these mechanisms in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with other microbes is not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC-derived isocyanides in Aspergillus fumigatus bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a source of fungal copper homeostasis molecules and that the xan BGC is a source of molecules that can mediate interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of interactions with other microbes and in the maintenance of copper homeostasis. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the geographic distribution of the species that are most vulnerable to frost damage. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and the support of the development of classic Th1 cells by Th17 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of disease pathogenesis and may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for drugs that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify new therapies for ALS. This will help to improve the quality of life for ALS patients and to increase the survival of those affected. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the pathogen. Mechanistically, the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence their insect vectors to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic in the history of tetrapods. The discovery of a new basal member of the group, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short tail and the evolution of the avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of its components. In this paper, we show that the behavior of the atmosphere is not as simple as we might think.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is a key feature for its survival, and is used for communication, camouflage, and other functions. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color is determined by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the development of breast cancer. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner, and is required for the development of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the fossil record. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing and nature of the carbon cycle perturbation are consistent with a link to global cooling and atmospheric CO2 increase. The timing of the extinction and the nature of the carbon cycle perturbation are critical to understanding the extinction and its aftermath. The new dates from China provide a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, and the timing of the carbon cycle perturbation. The new dates also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The new dates will be critical to understanding the extinction and its aftermath. The intestine is the largest immune organ, and intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. However, the molecular mechanisms of intestinal inflammation remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease.
