The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in the down-regulated conformation, which is the most prevalent in the virus. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help to design vaccines and antibodies that are effective against the virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population, and a 2.10-y reduction at birth and 3.05-y reduction at age 65 y for the Black and Latino populations, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the need for public health interventions to reduce the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 on racial and ethnic minority groups. (Less)

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of interest to chemists, physicists, and material scientists.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of fire activity over the past century. This has had the effect of warming the climate, but we also show that recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand its role in the future.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan to the symbiotic microbes of a squid is required for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, whose activity is modulated by the catabolism of the glycan. This glycan is not required for the colonization of the symbiotic organ, but is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is not essential for the host, but is required for the development of the symbiosis. Thus, the provision of a single glycan to the symbiotic microbes is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is not essential for the host, but is required for the development of the symbiosis.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to represent documents as topic sequences, and how to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method can be applied to many domains. We believe that our method will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is considered to be the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease was caused by Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that infects rodents. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the rodent reservoirs are located, were favorable for the spread of the disease to Europe. This suggests that the Black Death was not a single introduction of the bacterium, but rather the consequence of multiple introductions, which occurred over a period of 40 y. Our results provide evidence for the importance of climate in the spread of the disease. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss can have significant impacts on the ecosystem. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the sea star wasting disease, which has caused the loss of at least 90% of the population of some species. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a disease in a sea star.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, and a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The genetic structure is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the history of Madagascar, and they are relevant to the understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean. They also provide a reference for the study of the human history of the island. (Less)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress two other genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same translation site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings suggest that the protein is involved in the regulation of the dual-function RNA. This is the first report of a protein that is encoded by a dual-function RNA. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, and are the only source of information for many crops. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is the only source of information on crop status for many crops, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert assessments in agricultural monitoring systems.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to rely on the integration of information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The plastid genome is a unique genetic element, which has been shaped by the evolution of the host and the parasite. The evolutionary history of the plastid genome is a reflection of the evolutionary history of the host and the parasite. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a reminder that climate change is not a distant threat, but is already affecting people’s lives. We need to act now.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in a sample of sand from the Trinity test site, the first nuclear explosion, provides a unique link between the laboratory synthesis of quasicrystals and the history of the 20th century.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a subunit of the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased, and this increase is also due to human activities. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This increase in the probability of drought is likely to become more important as the climate continues to warm.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. It is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. It also provides a potential target for the development of a therapeutic strategy for autism. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In the absence of the CRAC channel, the cell is unable to respond to changes in the intracellular Ca2+ concentration. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of clinical abnormalities, including hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and muscle dysfunction. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and their subsequent accumulation in other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of lysosomes with the cell membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for cell growth. We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) in a manner that is effective in cancer cells. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of DLBCL that can be exploited for cancer therapy. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)
We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics with neutral atoms and to engineer exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and lived below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has allowed us to understand the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolutionary history of viruses in the past. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which are from human remains dating from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 thousand years old, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a clear sign of climate change. However, the rate of rise is not uniform around the world, and it is not clear why some regions are rising faster than others. Our results show that the rate of rise is accelerating because of climate change, and that the rate of rise is increasing with latitude.

Pain is a common and costly problem. It is expected that pain will increase with age, as the body accumulates wear and tear and disease. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain has been increasing for all adults, but that the increase has been more pronounced for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain experimentally. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex. This approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex, including the location of the substrate, the active site, and the substrate’s interaction with the enzyme. This approach is applicable to a wide range of enzymes and substrates, and can be used to understand the mechanism of action of enzymes. This approach can be used to understand the mechanism of action of enzymes, which is key to understanding how enzymes work and how they can be inhibited or used as a therapeutic target. This approach can also be used to understand the mechanism of action of enzymes, which is key to understanding how enzymes work and how they can be inhibited or used as a therapeutic target. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses. It may also be considered for the treatment of the recently emerged novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as the disease caused by this virus has caused a recent outbreak in China and has the potential to spread globally.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan to the symbiotic microbes of a squid is required for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulates the conditions in which they live. This work provides a new perspective on the role of nutrients in the maintenance of symbioses, and suggests that the provision of specific nutrients to specific symbionts may be a more general feature of animal-microbe interactions. (Show more)

This study shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved by encouraging teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This has the potential to reduce the use of suspension and other exclusionary discipline practices, which are associated with a range of negative outcomes. The intervention is scalable, requiring no additional resources, and can be implemented by teachers in a matter of minutes. It is also inexpensive to evaluate, requiring only a few minutes of teacher time. The intervention is available for free download at https://www.empathyschool.org/.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is known to cause mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for virus infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may help to explain the severe disease caused by MERS-CoV infection. (Show more)

The food system is a major contributor to environmental degradation and a major cause of global disease burden. The food system also has the potential to contribute to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, including those related to climate change and health. However, the food system is also a major contributor to inequality. This study provides evidence that a simple change to catering practices can have a large impact on the sustainability and healthfulness of the food system. This has the potential to contribute to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, including those related to climate change and health.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of six different breast cancer cell lines expressing the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its severity and rapid spread is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism of immune suppression. The structure provides a molecular understanding of the role of ORF8 in the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the release of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) from astrocytes, which in turn increases the influx of water into the brain and causes edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. But what if we have not learned from our experience? This is the problem of selective inference. We describe a number of recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. These methods are designed to help us learn from our experience. They are especially important in the era of big data.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional vasculature. However, the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs has not been achieved. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the conversion of human fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. These findings provide a promising approach for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of functional vasculature. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 as a therapeutic agent may be a promising strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The identification of “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) has led to the discovery of a number of important signaling pathways. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of one of these “orphan” RTKs, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk), is essential for the development of a specific type of pigment cells in the eye and the body. We also show that the zebrafish homolog of the other “orphan” RTK, leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk), is essential for the development of a specific type of pigment cells in the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between the two “orphan” RTKs and their ligands and demonstrate that the ligands are essential for the development of a specific type of pigment cells. This work provides insights into the function of these “orphan” RTKs and their ligands in vivo. (Show more)

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a new perspective for the role of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, based on their genome organization. The group that causes human influenza has a segmented genome, which is packaged into virions by a selective mechanism. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and sequence dependent. It favors the copackaging of interacting RNA segments and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. These results indicate that the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome is a complex process that involves a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The study of the vascular system is one of the most important fields of biomedical research. The vascular system is a complex network of tissues and cells that are constantly exposed to a variety of mechanical forces. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical mechanism in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millions of years. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has had a substantial impact on the environment and economy, and has increased the risk of wildfire to human communities. The expansion of the fire niche is driven by human activities, and is a direct result of the expansion of the human footprint.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropod pests remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the virus is thought to replicate within individual cells. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics within a single cell, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We find that the model is consistent with the available data and can be used to assess the effect of antiviral treatment. We also provide estimates of the number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. These estimates can be used to assess the effect of antiviral treatment on the viral load in the plasma. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a direct consequence of the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor model Drosophila melanogaster develops a dysbiotic microbiome and that the microbiome triggers a regenerative response that promotes tumor growth. We also show that the tumor-induced JNK/Mmp2 signaling leads to barrier dysfunction and that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing therapeutic strategies to control tumor growth. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy varies widely among patients. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is highly likely to have been triggered by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong climate response.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and food security. We find that river fisheries are concentrated in regions with high human population density and low levels of biodiversity protection. In addition, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect the ecosystem services that rivers provide. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, and is instead triggered by physical lesion of the neuron’s sensory dendrite. This form of regeneration is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that the regeneration we describe may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic variation in populations. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a key determinant of the rate of evolution. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is highly similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved in eukaryotes.

The brain is a highly complex system, and the study of its organization is a major challenge. In this study, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality to identify and characterize the resting state organization of the human brain. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. This study provides a new perspective on the organization of the human brain, which can be used to study the normal and pathological functioning of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is a key element in the regulation of gene expression. The existence of 5′ modifications in other RNAs, such as tRNA and rRNA, has been known for a long time. However, the existence of 5′ modifications in mRNAs has been debated for many years. Here we show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding suggests that 5′ NAD-RNA could play a role in the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the ability of the body to maintain a favorable state of health for a prolonged period after the resolution of the triggering event. In this study, we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the resolution of the triggering event in people with diabetes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the maintenance of the favorable state of health after resolution of the triggering event. This mechanism may be of interest to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes and its complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse mixture of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of tomato flavor chemistry and opens the door to the development of improved cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is a key driver of ecosystem functioning, and because it is likely to change in the future. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the impacts of climate change on ecosystem services will be more severe than previously thought.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which are thought to represent the global environment. These findings suggest that the organization of MEC cell types is more complex than previously thought. This work provides a framework for future studies of the organization of the MEC. (Show more)

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides insights into the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its potential role in health and disease. (Show more)

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a signal of how connected we feel to them. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connections, and it is used by us to assess the quality of our own connections.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a small region of the heart, and its function is tightly regulated. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and plays a role in the regulation of the electrical activity of the SAN. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN and contribute to the electrical activity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the function of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides evidence that Si and JA interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the cellular lipidome of murine macrophages and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. Furthermore, we show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the signaling of murine macrophages. These findings may help to understand the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in human health and disease.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to rely on the integration of information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides a wide range of goods and services to humans. However, the coastal zone is also a highly vulnerable ecosystem, as it is often the first area to be impacted by human activities. In this study, we show that the coastal zone is also a highly dynamic zone, as it is shaped by the inputs of nutrients from a wide range of watersheds. We demonstrate that the coastal zone is shaped by the inputs of nutrients from a wide range of watersheds, and that these inputs are highly variable. Our findings suggest that the coastal zone is a highly dynamic zone, shaped by the inputs of nutrients from a wide range of watersheds.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a random force. We argue that the observed behavior is a consequence of the interplay between the intrinsic dynamics of the network and the external forcing. Our results suggest that the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations may be a general feature of chemical networks. This may have important implications for the understanding of the origin and evolution of life.

The brain is a dynamic system, and the electrical activity of the brain is a reflection of the activity of the brain. In this study, we show that the electrical activity of the brain can be altered by a specific class of antibodies, which are used to treat a specific disease of the brain. This finding has implications for the study of the brain in general, and for the study of the electrical activity of the brain in particular.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the lack of data and the complexity of the processes involved. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the ocean floor. Our results provide insights into the processes involved in abrupt climate change and into the history of such events. They also provide a case study for the use of multiproxy and modeling approaches to reconstruct the history of abrupt climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate sustainability commitments. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that the impact is small and limited to areas that are already deforested. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our findings highlight the need for more effective regulation of the palm oil industry.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of proteins and vesicles from the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and can be used to study the regulation of exocytosis in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potential drug target for human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination allele, sex is binary, with two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, sex is polygenic, with multiple genotypic sexes. In species with polygenic sex determination, the sex determination locus can be decoupled from the sex of the adult. Here we show that decoupling sex determination from adult sex in a fish species results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive carbonyl species (RCS) that are generated by photooxidation of endogenous molecules. These species can damage the retina and contribute to the development of age-related macular degeneration. We show that the levels of iron (Fe) in the retina can influence the formation of reactive carbonyl species that can damage the retina. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the organization of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not a dead end, and that it can be linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of predator specialization in the context of the evolution of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for cell growth. We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) in a manner that is effective in cancer cells. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of DLBCL that can be exploited for cancer therapy. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is often blamed for the loss of biodiversity and the degradation of natural resources. However, it is also a major contributor to food insecurity and malnutrition in many parts of the world. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of natural forests. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting food and nutrition security goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but it has also led to the compaction of the soil, which is detrimental to soil functioning. We show that the use of farm machinery has led to the development of a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, which is now widespread over arable land. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the ecological history of the largest animals that walked Earth. (Show more)
